title: Lactic acid bacteria population dynamics during minced beef storage under aerobic or modified atmosphere packaging conditions
abstract: A total of 266 lactic acid bacteria (LAB) have been isolated from minced beef stored at 0, 5, 10 and 15 °C aerobically and under modified atmosphere packaging consisting of 40% CO2–30% O2–30% N2 in the presence MAP (+) and absence MAP (−) of oregano essential oil. Sequencing of their 16S rRNA gene along with presence of the katA gene demonstrated dominance of the LAB microbiota by Leuconostoc spp. during aerobic storage at 5, 10 and 15 °C, as well as during MAP (−) and MAP (+) storage at 10 and 15 °C; Lactobacillus sakei prevailed during aerobic storage at 0 °C, as well as at MAP (−) and MAP (+) storage at 0 and 5 °C. The sporadic presence of other species such as Leuconostoc mesenteroides, Weisella viridescens, Lactobacillus casei and Lactobacillus curvatus has also been determined. Pulsed-Field Gel Electrophoresis of high molecular weight genomic DNA revealed the dynamics of the isolated LAB strains. Prevalence of Leuconostoc spp. was attributed to one strain only. On the other hand, packaging conditions affected Lb. sakei strain spoilage dynamics

Accepted Manuscript
Title: Lactic acid bacteria population dynamics during minced beef storage under
aerobic or modified atmosphere packaging conditions
Authors: Agapi I. Doulgeraki, Spiros Paramithiotis, Dafni-Maria Kagkli, George–John
E. Nychas
PII: S0740-0020(10)00179-6
DOI: 10.1016/j.fm.2010.07.004
Reference: YFMIC 1465
To appear in: Food Microbiology
Received Date: 13 November 2009
Revised Date: 27 June 2010
Accepted Date: 6 July 2010
Please cite this article as: Doulgeraki, A.I., Paramithiotis, S., Kagkli, D.-M., Nychas, D.-J.E. Lactic
acid bacteria population dynamics during minced beef storage under aerobic or modified atmosphere
packaging conditions, Food Microbiology (2010), doi: 10.1016/j.fm.2010.07.004

 Title: Lactic acid bacteria population dynamics during minced beef storage under aerobic or 1 
modified atmosphere packaging conditions 2 
 3 
Running title: LAB strains spoilage dynamics 4 
 5 
 6 
Agapi I. Doulgeraki,1,3 Spiros Paramithiotis,2 Dafni - Maria Kagkli,1 and George – John,  E. 7 
Nychas1* 8 
 9 
Department of Food Science, Technology and Human Nutrition, 10 
 
1Laboratory of Microbiology and Biotechnology of Foods, 11 
 2Laboratory of Food Quality Control and Hygiene, Agricultural University of Athens, Iera 12 
Odos 75, Athens 11855, Greece 13 
3
 Applied Mycology Group, Cranfield Health, Cranfield University, Bedford MK43 0AL, UK  14 
 15 
 16 
*Corresponding author. Mailing address: Agricultural University of Athens, Laboratory of 17 
Microbiology and Biotechnology of Foods, Iera Odos 75, Athens 11855, Greece. Phone: +30 18 
210 5294938. Fax: +30 210 5294938. E-mail: gjn@aua.gr. 19 
 20 
 21 
 22 
 23 
 24 
 25 
 2 
 
ABSTRACT 26 
 27 
A total of 266 lactic acid bacteria (LAB) have been isolated from minced beef stored 28 
at 0, 5, 10 and 15°C aerobically and under modified atmosphere packaging consisting of  29 
40% CO2 - 30% O2 - 30% N2 in the presence MAP (+) and absence MAP (-) of oregano 30 
essential oil. Sequencing of their 16S rRNA gene along with presence of the katA gene 31 
demonstrated dominance of the LAB microbiota by Leuconostoc spp. during aerobic storage 32 
at 5, 10 and 15°C, as well as during MAP (-) and MAP (+) storage at 10 and 15°C; 33 
Lactobacillus sakei prevailed during aerobic storage at 0°C, as well as at MAP (-) and MAP 34 
(+) storage at 0 and 5° C. The sporadic presence of other species such as Leuconostoc 35 
mesenteroides, Weisella viridescens,  Lactobacillus casei and Lactobacillus curvatus has also 36 
been determined. Pulsed-Field Gel Electrophoresis of high molecular weight genomic DNA 37 
revealed the dynamics of the isolated LAB strains. Prevalence of Leuconostoc spp. was 38 
attributed to one strain only. On the other hand, packaging conditions affected Lb. sakei strain 39 
spoilage dynamics.  40 
 41 
 42 
 43 
 44 
 45 
Key words; Lactic acid bacteria, meat preservation, PFGE, essential oils, microbial ecology 46 
 47 
 48 
 49 
 50 
 3 
 
INTRODUCTION 51 
Food spoilage microbiota has been the subject of several studies conducted so far; the 52 
ones focused on meat and meat products were based on the identification and/or 53 
characterization of the dominant microbiota at different storage conditions. The concept of 54 
‘succession’ of spoilage-related microbial groups i.e. ephemeral / specific spoilage organisms 55 
(E/SSO), was only recently, taken into consideration (Ercolini et al. 2006; Chenoll et al. 56 
2007; Nychas et al. 2008).  57 
Lactic acid bacteria (LAB) for instance are considered to be the Specific Spoilage 58 
Organisms (SSO) that contribute to the meat spoilage stored under packaging conditions in 59 
which the concentration of carbon dioxide is increased (Axelsson 1998; Holzapfel 1998; 60 
Nychas and Skandamis 2005). Lactobacillus, Leuconostoc and Carnobacterium are among 61 
the most frequently encountered genera on vacuum or modified atmosphere packaged meat 62 
and play an important role in the spoilage of refrigerated raw meat (Shaw and Harding 1984; 63 
Dainty and Mackey 1992; Hugas et al. 1993; McMullen and Stiles 1993; Rovira et al. 1997; 64 
Holzapfel 1998; Labadie 1999; Parente et al. 2001; Nychas and Skandamis 2005). Species of 65 
Leuconostoc sp. and Lb. sakei have been associated with the spoilage of vacuum or modified 66 
atmosphere packed meat stored at chill temperatures (Champomier – Verges et al., 2001; 67 
Yost and Nattress 2002; Ercolini et al. 2006). The lack of consistency e.g. why these two 68 
species were not always found at the end of storage period even if the conditions were similar 69 
can be possibly attributed not only to the limitation of the applied methodologies used but 70 
also to the potential effect of the man imposed preservation system on the development of the 71 
microbial association, e.g., Ephemeral Spoilage Organism (Stanbridge and Davies 1998; 72 
Nychas et al. 2008; Vasilopoulos et al., 2010). In this case the word ‘ephemeral’ does 73 
describe the situation where these specific spoilage bacteria contribute to meat spoilage for a 74 
very short period of time till the next climax population is established. The identification and 75 
 4 
 
characterization of these ESOs in raw meat under different storage conditions remains still to 76 
be elucidated (Jones 2004; Ercolini 2006, 2009; Fontana 2006; Vasilopoulos et al. 2010).  77 
  Oregano essential oil, as a potential `hurdle', was found to affect the contribution of 78 
spoilage microorganisms to the microbial association as well as to the physico-chemical 79 
changes of the minced meat (Skandamis and Nychas 2001, Burt 2004). Skandamis and 80 
Nychas (2002) that reported the oregano essential oil effect on microbial population, 81 
including LAB, on active packaging conditions. Axelsson (1998) concluded that the addition 82 
of oregano essential oil influenced the metabolic activity of LAB. More specifically, the 83 
initial heterofermentative microbiota was substituted by an homofermentative one at the end 84 
of storage. However, despite the antimicrobial action of essential oil on biota, there is less 85 
information about the effect of such compounds on the microbial diversity of the LAB 86 
isolated from meat at species and strain level. The only information available relates the 87 
essential oil effect on growth of meat spoilage bacteria such as Lb. sakei, Lb. curvatus and 88 
Carnobacterium piscicola (Ouattara et al. 1997). 89 
 The use of conventional phenotypic methods does not always allow efficient 90 
characterization of the microbiota at species level (Holzapfel 1998; Stanbridge and Davies 91 
1998). On the contrary, molecular identification and characterization tools are far more 92 
consistent, rapid, reliable and reproducible and can discriminate even between closely related 93 
groups of species, which are otherwise indistinguishable on the basis of their phenotype. The 94 
advances in molecular techniques are expected to widen the knowledge of spoilage-related 95 
bacterial succession during storage of foods (Chenoll et al. 2003; Ercolini et al. 2006). 96 
Several molecular typing techniques have been developed during the past decade for the 97 
identification and classification of bacteria at strain level. Among them, Pulsed-Field Gel 98 
Electrophoresis (PFGE) of DNA fragments resulting from the digestion of whole genomic 99 
DNAs with rare-cutting restriction endonucleases has proved to be reliable for bacterial 100 
 5 
 
typing. This method has been used to differentiate members of several genera including 101 
Lactococcus (Tanskanen et al. 1990), Clostridia (Hiel et al. 1998), Streptomyces (Leblond et 102 
al. 1990), probiotic lactobacilli (Yeung et al. 2004), and to compare the genomic restriction 103 
patterns of five Bifidobacterium breve strains (Bourget et al. 1993). It is considered to be a 104 
discriminating and reproducible method to differentiate strains of intestinal bacteria (O’ 105 
Sullivan 1999) and for chromosome size estimation in Lb. acidophilus (Roussel et al. 1993, 106 
Sanders et al. 1996), Lb. plantarum (Daniel 1995), and other LAB (Tanskanen et al. 1990). 107 
Furthermore, PFGE in association with PCR-based methods are commonly used for strain 108 
monitoring (Singh et al. 2009). 109 
 The aim of the present study was to systematically monitor the microbial diversity of 110 
LAB, isolated from meat stored at different temperatures and under different packaging e.g. 111 
aerobic or MAP conditions, at strain level, by using modern molecular tools. 112 
 113 
MATERIALS AND METHODS 114 
Sample preparation and storage conditions. Minced beef was purchased from the central 115 
market of Athens and prepared according to Argyri et al. (submitted for publication). Briefly, 116 
minced beef samples were stored at 0, 5, 10 and 15oC, aerobically or under modified 117 
atmospheres packaging (MAP) consisting of 40% CO2 - 30% O2 - 30% N2 with MAP (+) or 118 
without MAP (-) the application of volatile compounds of oregano essential oil (2% v/w). 119 
The samples were placed on Styrofoam trays; all trays were performed to allow the diffusion 120 
of the volatile compounds of the essential oil with both side of the samples. In the case of the 121 
treated samples (MAP +), the essential oil was distributed on a whatman paper that was 122 
placed on the bottom side of the tray. 123 
  124 
 6 
 
Sampling of the meat. Minced beef was sampled at appropriate time intervals, depending on 125 
storage temperature; the incubation lasted 650, 482, 386 and 220 hours at 0, 5, 10 and 15oC, 126 
respectively and all samples were analysed in dublicate. A detailed description of the 127 
methodology employed for the enumeration of the total viable counts, Pseudomonas spp., Br. 128 
thermosphacta, LAB, Enterobacteriaceae, yeasts and molds in this work is presented 129 
elsewhere (Argyri et al. submitted for publication). Briefly, LAB counts were determined on 130 
ΜRS agar (Biolife, Italiana S.r.l., Milano, Italy) (pH = 5.8) overlaid with the same medium 131 
and incubated at 30 ˚C for 72 h. LAB were isolated from the highest dilution from three 132 
different time points (initial, middle and final stage of storage) for further analysis; 10% of 133 
the colonies (6 to 10 colonies) derived from plate culture of the highest sample dilution. They 134 
were randomly selected  and purified by successive subculture on MRS agar at 30°C. Gram 135 
positive, catalase and oxidase negative isolates were stored at -80˚C in MRS broth (Biolife, 136 
Milano, Italy) supplemented with 20% (v/v) glycerol (Merck, Darmstadt, Germany) until 137 
further use. Before experimental use each strain was grown twice in MRS broth at 30°C for 138 
24 and 16h respectively. Purity of the culture was always checked on MRS agar plates before 139 
use. 140 
 141 
Pulsed-Field Gel Electrophoresis (PFGE). PFGE was performed according to Kagkli et al. 142 
(2007). Briefly, cells were harvested by centrifugation at 10,000 x g for 5 min and washed 143 
with 10 mM Tris-HCl (pH 7.6) containing 1 M NaCl; resuspended in 100 µL of the same 144 
solution, heated at 37°C for 10 min and mixed with an equal volume of 2% (w/v) low 145 
melting-point agarose (Bio-Rad, Hercules, CA, USA) in 0.125 M EDTA pH 7.6 before 146 
letting them to solidify in moulds (Bio-Rad). The cells were lysed in situ in a solution 147 
containing 10 mg mL-1 of lysozyme in EC buffer (6 mM Tris-HCl, 1 M NaCl, 100 mM 148 
EDTA, 1% (w/v) Sarkosyl, pH 7.6) for 16 h at 37°C. The lytic treatment was repeated with 149 
 7 
 
the same solution containing 2U mL-1 mutanolysin. After treatment with proteinase K (0.5Μ 150 
EDTA containing 1% sarkosyl, pH 8) for 24h at 55°C, the agarose blocks were washed twice 151 
for 1 h with 1 mM phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride (PMSF) in 10 mM Tris-HCl containing 1 152 
mM EDTA, (pH 8.0) at 37°C and then stored at 4°C in 10 mM Tris-HCl containing 100 mM 153 
EDTA (pH 8.0) until further use. 154 
The agarose blocks were cut with sterile coverslips and slices (1 - 2 mm thick) of the 155 
blocks were washed three times at room temperature in 10 mM Tris-HCl containing 0.1 mM 156 
EDTA (pH 8.0) for 30 min with gentle agitation. The restriction enzymes ApaI and SmaI 157 
(10U) (New England Biolabs, Ipswich, MA, USA) were initially selected to digest the slices 158 
of a limited number of strains. The enzyme that resulted in the production of clearer and 159 
sharper PFGE digestion profile was used for the digestion of all isolates. Digestions were 160 
performed according to the recommendations of the manufacturer. 161 
Following digestion, slices were loaded into wells of a 1% PFGE grade agarose gel (Bio-162 
Rad) and the gel was run in 0.5 mM Tris-Borate buffer (45 mM Tris–HCl, 45 mM Boric acid, 163 
1 mM EDTA) using a CHEF-DRII PFGE apparatus and cooling module (Bio-Rad) at 6 Volt 164 
cm-1 for 16h, with a pulse time ramped from 1 to 10s. Gels were then stained with ethidium 165 
bromide (0.5 µg ml-1) in water for 1 h and destained for 2 h before being photographed using 166 
a GelDoc system (Bio-Rad). Conversion, normalization and further analysis were performed 167 
using the Pearson coefficient and UPGMA cluster analysis with Gel compare software, 168 
version 4.0 (Applied Maths, Sint-Martens-Latem, Belgium; kindly provided by E. 169 
Tsakalidou, Dairy Laboratory, Agricultural University of Athens). 170 
 171 
DNA extraction and species identification. DNA was extracted according to the 172 
protocol described by the manufacturer of GenElute Bacterial Genomic DNA Kit (Sigma, 173 
Chemical Co., St. Louis, Mo. USA). Representative number of isolates per distinct PFGE 174 
 8 
 
cluster were selected and subjected to species identification by sequencing the V1-V3 175 
variable region of the 16S rRNA gene as described previously (Paramithiotis et al. 2008). 176 
PCR products were purified using the QIAquick® PCR Purification Kit (Qiagen, Hilden, 177 
Germany) according to the manufacturer’s instructions and directly sequenced with an ABI 178 
3730 XL automatic DNA sequencer by Macrogen (http://www.macrogen.com). The results 179 
were aligned with those in GenBank using the BLASTN program in order to determine their 180 
closest known relatives of the partial 16S rRNA gene sequence (Altschul et al. 1997). The 181 
GenBank/EMBL/DDBJ accession numbers for the 16S-rRNA gene sequences are GU998850 182 
to GU998881 (Table 2). 183 
 184 
Detection of the heme - dependent catalase (katA) gene. All isolates were screened by 185 
PCR for the presence of the katA gene, encoding heme-dependent catalase (Knauf et al. 186 
1992; Hertel et al. 1998). For this purpose the specific primers 702-F (5’-187 
AATTGCCTTCTTCCGTGTA-3’, position 551–536) and 310-R (5’-188 
AGTTGCGCACAATTATTTTC-3’, position 127–139) were used.  189 
 190 
 191 
RESULTS 192 
 193 
LAB were found to be the dominant biota in samples stored under MAP 194 
supplemented (+) or not (-) with Essential Oil (EO) (results not shown – Argyri et al. 195 
submitted for publication). Table 1 summarizes the lactic acid bacterial counts of the initial 196 
biota and of the three different time points (initial, middle and final stage of storage) for each 197 
of the storage conditions tested. In case of samples stored under MAP (+), the counts of LAB 198 
were lower at two times points (middle, end) than the ones stored in air and under MAP (-). 199 
 9 
 
A total of 266 LAB isolates were recovered throughout the storage period; 99 isolates 200 
from aerobic storage, 89 isolates from MAP (-) and 78 isolates from MAP (+).  The 99 201 
isolates from aerobic storage were subjected to PFGE to determine the strain diversity during 202 
storage. For the aforementioned isolates, high molecular weight genomic DNA was digested 203 
with two different restriction enzymes (ApaI and SmaI). ApaI restriction generated better 204 
distributed bands than SmaI allowing a more reliable analysis of the generated profiles (Fig 205 
1). Therefore, ApaI was chosen to digest the 89 and 78 isolates from minced beef stored 206 
under MAP (-) and MAP (+), respectively.  207 
A large diversity regarding strain occurrence at the different packaging and 208 
temperature conditions was revealed (Fig 1, Table 3). The dendrogram obtained after image 209 
analysis of the different PFGE patterns, resulted into 32 different profiles, nine of which were 210 
obtained from aerobic storage, while 15 and 17 from MAP (-) and MAP (+), respectively 211 
(Table 3). Each strain present in Figure 1 was subjected to 16S rRNA gene sequencing. 212 
Strains B 225, B 251, B 226, B 236, B 248, B 253, B 228, B 237, B 229, B 255, B 227, B 213 
239, B 230, B 238, B 250, B 252, B 254 and B 249 were assigned to Lb. sakei; strains B 245 214 
and B 246 to Lb. curvatus; strain B 247 to Lb. casei-group; strains B 234 and B 235 to Ws. 215 
viridescens; strains B 242 and B 243 to Ln. mesenteroides-group and strains B 232, B 241, B 216 
258, B 244, B 233, B 240 and B 231 to Leuconostoc spp. All isolates were also screened for 217 
the presence of the katA gene, specific for Lb. sakei. The katA amplification results were in 218 
accordance with the ones already described. Two fingerprints (B 232 and B 233 assigned to 219 
Leuconostoc spp.) were common for all packaging conditions, two (B 226 and B 227 220 
assigned to Lb. sakei) were shared between air and MAP (-), one fingerprint (B 230 assigned 221 
to Lb. sakei) was shared between air and MAP (+), and two fingerprints (B 242 and B 243 222 
assigned to Ln. mesenteroides) were shared between MAP (-) and MAP (+). 223 
 10 
 
From the initial stage of storage, two different strains (B 232 and B 233) were 224 
recovered, which were assigned to Leuconostoc spp. Strain B 233 was the most common 225 
isolate, since it was recovered at a percentage of 83.33% of the isolates recovered from the 226 
initial stage of storage. 227 
From the 99 isolates from the aerobic storage of minced beef, the largest group was 228 
attributed to Leuconostoc spp. The corresponding fingerprints were B 231, B 232 and B 233 , 229 
with the latter being the most common isolate, representing the dominant biota during storage 230 
at 5, 10 and 15°C. The rest of the fingerprints (B 225, B 226, B 227, B 228, B 229 and B 230) 231 
were attributed to Lb. sakei, which were recovered from 0 and 5°C, but one (B 228) from 232 
10°C. At 0°C, Lb. sakei (B 226) was the prevalent one at the final stage of storage. The 233 
frequency of isolation and prevalence of the aforementioned  isolates obtained from minced 234 
beef regarding aerobic storage at 0, 5, 10 and 15°C is shown in Table 3. 235 
Fifteen different fingerprints were detected during storage of minced beef under MAP 236 
(-); they were assigned to Lb. sakei (B 226, B 227, B 236, B 237, B 238 and B 239), 237 
Leuconostoc spp. (B 232, B233, B 258, B 240 and B 241), Ws. viridescens (B 234 and B 238 
235), and Ln. mesenteroides (B 242 and B 243).  Table 3 presents the frequency of isolation 239 
and prevalence of the isolates regarding the storage temperature. At 10 and 15°C, 240 
Leuconostoc spp. (B 233) represented the dominant biota, whilst Ws. viridescens (B 234), Lb. 241 
sakei (B 237), Ln. mesenteroides (B 243) and Leuconostoc spp. (B 240) were also recovered. 242 
At chill temperatures (0 and 5°C), the strain diversity was increased, since 11 different 243 
fingerprints were recovered. In both temperatures, Lb. sakei (B 237) was the prevalent strain 244 
at the final stage of storage. Moreover, Lb. sakei (B 236, B 238 and B 239), and Leuconostoc 245 
spp. (B 233 and B 258) were also recovered from storage at 0°C, whilst Ws. viridescens (B 246 
235), Lb. sakei (B 226, B 238 and B 227), Leuconostoc spp. (B 233 and B 241) and Ln. 247 
mesenteroides (B 242) were recovered from storage at 5°C. 248 
 11 
 
Out of 78 isolates, seventeen different fingerprints were obtained during storage of 249 
minced beef under MAP (+), indicating the increased diversity of the isolates. The frequency 250 
of isolation and prevalence of these isolates regarding storage at 0, 5, 10 and 15°C is shown 251 
in Table 3. At 10 and 15°C, Leuconostoc spp. (B 233) was the most common isolate, 252 
representing the dominant strain, whilst Lb. sakei (B 252 and B 255) and Ln. mesenteroides 253 
(B 243) were also recovered. Lb. sakei (B 254) was the dominant strain at the final stage of 254 
storage at 5°C, while Lb. sakei (B 248 and B 255),  and Leuconostoc spp. (B 233 and B 244) 255 
were also recovered during the storage at 5°C. At the final stage of storage at 0°C, 256 
Leuconostoc spp. (B 233), Ln. mesenteroides (B 242), Lb. curvatus (B 246) and Lb. sakei (B 257 
249 and  B 251) were equally contributed. Lb. curvatus (B 245), Lb. casei and Lb. sakei (B 258 
248, B 250 and B 253) were also recovered during storage at 0°C.   259 
 260 
DISCUSSION 261 
 262 
Spoilage and spoilage progress of meat and meat products have been the subject of 263 
several studies conducted so far (Borch et al. 1996; Stanbridge and Davies 1998; Labadie 264 
1999; Skandamis and Nychas 2002; Nychas and Skandamis 2005; Nychas et al. 2008). 265 
Nevertheless, meat spoilage has only been associated with the physicochemical and 266 
microbiological analysis of the bacterial loads ignoring the spoilage potential of a specific 267 
bacterial species or strain (Skandamis and Nychas 2002). Only recently did research took into 268 
consideration the specific characteristics of  the  spoilage microbiota of the meat products and 269 
its contribution to the deterioration of the product (Cocolin et al. 2004; Rantsiou et al. 2005; 270 
Ercolini et al. 2006, 2009; Vasilopoulos et al. 2010).  271 
The present study focused on the evaluation of the microbial diversity of LAB 272 
isolated from minced beef stored under different storage conditions at strain level. Storage 273 
 12 
 
conditions had an important effect on the diversity of the microbial population, since different 274 
strains were recovered during the storage of meat under different conditions. These findings 275 
strengthen the opinion that the storage temperature and the modified atmosphere packaging 276 
affect the spoilage potential of LAB (Stanbringe and Davies 1998; Ercolini et al. 2006, 2009). 277 
Moreover, this observation can be explained by the fact that different metabolic activities 278 
occur when different species/strains are present and when meat is stored under specific 279 
conditions. Not all species belonging to the same bacterial group, e.g., LAB, necessarily grow 280 
at the same temperature. It might therefore be misleading the fact that selective media only 281 
are used for the determination of the spoilage biota. Further characterization of the isolates 282 
grown on the selective plates should be demanded if a better insight and understanding of the 283 
phenomenon is required. This is in accordance with the observations of Ercolini et al, (2006) 284 
who reported that different species / strains were isolated from beef although similar counts 285 
were determined. Ercolini et al. (2006) also mentioned that the viable counts alone may not 286 
be enough to highlight the shifts of the bacterial communities depending on the 287 
environmental changes and species that are actually involved in meat spoilage. 288 
Among the species listed in Table 2, several meat associated ones were identified. 289 
Holzapfel (1998) reported that more rarely Lb. plantarum and Lb. casei are associated with 290 
meat systems and in lower frequency and numbers than Lb. curvatus and Lb. sakei; the 291 
presence of Ws. viridescens in raw meat has been also described. Moreover, Lb. curvatus, Lb. 292 
sakei and Leuconostoc spp. have been found to indicate a mixture community of vacuum 293 
packed (vp) beef (Yost and Nattress 2002). Leuconostocs have been identified as 294 
predominant organisms in beef stored under vp/MAP (Stanbringe and Davis 1998; Yost and 295 
Nattress 2002) and their presence in the initial mesophilic bacterial microbiota is very 296 
frequent (Borch et al. 1996). Lb. sakei has been associated with fresh meat (Champomier – 297 
Verges et al. 2001) as well as spoilage of a variety of meat products both under vacuum and 298 
 13 
 
modified atmosphere packaging (Ercolini et al. 2006, 2009) and it is known to be among the 299 
most psychrotrophic lactobacilli. It has also been found to be the dominant spoilage LAB 300 
during storage at chill temperatures (Ercolini et al. 2006; Chenoll et al. 2007). 301 
PFGE has also provided important information in relation to the strain distribution of 302 
the LAB population which would have not been acquired if strain typing had not been 303 
performed. Within the LAB population of the present study, Leuconostoc spp. and Lb. sakei 304 
were identified as significant members of the microbiota at abuse and chill temperatures, 305 
respectively. More accurately, Leuconostoc spp. (B 233) that was initially present at high 306 
levels, dominated eventually the microbiota of the minced beef stored at abuse temperatures 307 
at all packaging conditions. Although, it was persistent throughout storage at chill 308 
temperatures, Lb. sakei strains dominated the LAB population only at the final stage of 309 
storage. However, some degree of microbial variability was detected at the final stage of 310 
storage of meat at chill temperatures, since different Lb. sakei strains were the most prevalent 311 
ones at the different packaging conditions. Indeed, Lb. sakei (B 226), (B 237) and (B 245) 312 
dominated the LAB population at 0°C under aerobic conditions, at 0 and 5°C under MAP (-) 313 
and at 5°C under MAP (+).  This finding is of great importance since it shows the 314 
intraspecies variability of Lb. sakei and the ability of certain strains to adapt to the different 315 
storage conditions outgrowing the other.  316 
Dominance of Leuconostoc spp. at relatively higher temperatures can be partially 317 
attributed to the favourable environmental conditions and partially to the shorter generation 318 
time (Harris 1998), both of which enabled it to outgrow Lb. sakei strains which were indeed 319 
detected as a secondary microbiota. On the other hand, dominance of Lb. sakei strains at chill 320 
temperatures can be attributed partly to its psychrotrophic nature. 321 
From the different LAB detected throughout the storage under MAP (-) and MAP (+), 322 
a wide range of strains were sporadically present, especially at chill temperatures. This 323 
 14 
 
finding indicates that modified atmosphere packaging resulted in a development of a totally 324 
different spoilage ecosystem. It has been previously reported (Jay 2000), that during storage 325 
of meat under MAP, the initial heterofermentative microbiota was substituted by a 326 
homofermentative one at the end of storage. Moreover, the MAP and the presumed activity of 327 
oregano essential oil against heterofermentative LAB species (Axelsson 1998) seem to have 328 
provided the latter with an ecological advantage over leuconostocs.  329 
The findings of the present study were based on the culture-dependent approach, most 330 
frequently applied when storage studies are performed. Selective media have been used for 331 
isolation and subsequent characterisation of the microbiota; stressed or injured cells might not 332 
have managed to recover and grow, resulting in their non isolation from the plates and giving 333 
therefore the impression that they were absence from the system under investigation. A bias 334 
is therefore inserted which could have an effect on the description of the microbial 335 
community present. Except from the factors mentioned above, random selection of colonies 336 
is required to have a representative sample. This is not always possible because it depends on 337 
the person performing the task and it is therefore not objective. 338 
A culture-independent approach could have been an alternative to the plates used for 339 
the characterization of the different microbiota (Cocolin et al. 2004). Nevertheless, even this 340 
approach has drawbacks which lie in the fact that species have to be above the detection limit 341 
(104 cfu g-1) and very frequently, the dominant species prevents evidence of the less abundant 342 
ones. Primer affinity to the target has also an effect on the amplification and therefore on the 343 
species identified. In order to clarify possible discrepancies between culture-dependent and 344 
independent methods, and to evaluate whether these differences would give a different 345 
overview of the ecology of the meat stored at the conditions mentioned, a similar study could 346 
be performed applying both approaches in the future. This investigation lies beyond the scope 347 
of the present study, which was actually focused on elucidating the effect of the different 348 
 15 
 
storage conditions with or without the presence of essential oil on the dynamics of LAB 349 
strains. 350 
The present study did provide an insight of the population dynamics of LAB strains in 351 
relation to the temperature and the packaging conditions. It has been clearly demonstrated 352 
that certain species and/or strains are present or dominant only under certain conditions. This 353 
finding is extremely important since studies conducted so far had only taken into 354 
consideration the microbiological counts as an indication of the spoilage process, and had 355 
ignored the possibility that different species or strains would prevail under different storage 356 
and/or packaging conditions. The qualitative information derived from the microbiological 357 
analyses and the characterization of the species or even the strains present were not evaluated 358 
previously. It has been shown that storage temperature combined with packaging conditions 359 
induced the selectivity of the spoilage LAB microbiota. Moreover, the microbiota recovered 360 
from the initial stage of storage was markedly different from that of the final stage of storage 361 
at chill temperatures. The above observations are of great importance and, to our opinion, 362 
fundamental in understanding the spoilage process and in explaining the presence of different 363 
products or by-products that occur during the different dynamic storage conditions 364 
(Skandamis and Nychas 2002).  365
